title: Fix typo in PowerShellExecutionHelper.cs

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

* Have Git for Windows installed
* Run Powershell 7.21 (either in ConHost or the new Terminal app, bug is reproducible in both)
* Create the following simple function:
```
function Test-Ansi {
    $VerbosePreference = 'Continue'
    Write-Verbose '------ Before ------'
    & "$Env:ProgramFiles\Git\usr\bin\patch.exe" --help > $null
    Write-Verbose '------ After ------'
}
```
* Observe properly formatted coloring for the line before
* Observe line after being uncolored and ANSI sequences instead printed verbatim

# Additional Notes

This behaviour was only observed in PowerShell 7 - running the same function on PowerShell 5 yields the expected behaviour with no breaking changes to the ANSI output. 

It also doesn't make a difference whether the redirection is done via `| Out-Null` or doing a `$null` assignment. Even just redirecting stderr via `2>$null` triggers the issue. _Not_ redirecting the command is the only way to have it run without breaking.

The issue also occurs independent of invocation, `Invoke-Expression` results in this bug as does using `Start-Command`.

Also running this slightly tweaked function:
```
function Test-Ansi-Async {
    $VerbosePreference = 'Continue'
    Write-Verbose '------ Before ------'
    Start-Process -FilePath "C:\Program Files\Git\usr\bin\patch.exe" -RedirectStandardOutput NUL -ArgumentList '--help' -NoNewWindow
    Write-Verbose '------ After ------'
}
```
will yield different bugs in ConHost or Windows Terminal:

* In ConHost browsing through command history will have corrupted output, with characters remaining on screen between history items
* In Windows Terminal the ANSI color codes of the next command will be corruped

(See screenshots for each case).

In both cases pressing "Enter" without any input restores proper output at the prompt.

### Expected behavior

```console
VERBOSE: ------ Before ------
VERBOSE: ------ After ------
```


### Actual behavior

```console
VERBOSE: ------ Before ------
←[33;1mVERBOSE: ------ After ------←[0m
```


### Error details

```console
PS C:\Windows\System32› Get-Error
PS C:\Windows\System32›
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.22000
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

# Visual Corruption in ConHost

![2022-01-20_ConHost-ANSI-Bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9436503/150246602-cb223f99-dd1d-48d4-b0b4-a640910e4801.png)

# Broken ANSI Codes in Windows Terminal

![2022-01-20_Terminal-ANSI-Bug](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/9436503/150246904-8c27fbb4-e203-490b-a272-66bfbbc3b0a1.png)

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

This is a follow-up issue to issue #5661 I reported a few years back and I would like some insight into how this setup is different.

My new code has been following the "manifest module" pattern as laid out in the Pester documentation here:
https://github.com/pester/Pester/wiki/Testing-different-module-types#usage-and-workarounds

Here is their snippet for reference:
```powershell
@{
ModuleVersion     = '1.0'

RootModule        = "MyModule.psm1"

NestedModules     = @( "Invoke-PrivateManifestMethod.ps1", "Invoke-PublicManifestMethod.ps1" )
FunctionsToExport = @( "Invoke-PublicManifestMethod" )
}
```

This pattern works well for private and public PowerShell functions, it also works decently well for classes, except those that need to be exposed in the `ValidateSet` attribute. If I were to publish this I would likely merge the files, as I've heard dot-sourcing (which I assume is similar to `NestedModules`) can have performance issues, but I would still expect this to work locally.

To produce the issue, create the following folder structure and files:

```
\--PSTest
   |--Classes
      |--ValidateSet.ps1
   |--Public
      |--Test-ValidateSet.ps1
   |--PSTest.psd1
   |--PSTest.psm1
```

**ValidateSet.ps1**:
```powershell
using namespace System.Management.Automation

class TestValuesGenerator :  IValidateSetValuesGenerator {

    [string[]] GetValidValues() {
        return 1, 2, 3
    }

}
```

**Test-ValidateSet.ps1**:
```powershell
# Also does not work.
# . $PSScriptRoot/../Classes/ValidateSet.ps1

function Test-ValidateSet {
    param (
        [ValidateSet([TestValuesGenerator])]
        [string] $IWantValidValues
    )
}
```

**PSTest.psd1**:
```powershell
...

# Modules to import as nested modules of the module specified in RootModule/ModuleToProcess
NestedModules = @('Classes/ValidateSet.ps1', 'Public/Test-ValidateSet.ps1')

# Functions to export from this module, for best performance, do not use wildcards and do not delete the entry, use an empty array if there are no functions to export.
FunctionsToExport = @('Test-ValidateSet', 'Test-ValidateSetInModule')

...
```

**PSTest.psm1**:
```powershell
# Also does not work.
# . $PSScriptRoot/Classes/ValidateSet.ps1

function Test-ValidateSetInModule {
    param (
        [ValidateSet([TestValuesGenerator])]
        [string] $IWantValidValues
    )
}
```

At the moment, the only workaround I've found is literally putting a copy of the class in any file that needs it or putting all the classes for `ValidateSet` exposure into their own module and using the `using module` expression. Neither is overly convenient. 

**Edit:
I can also use the `ScriptsToProcess` attribute, that brings the class into session scope which may or may not be a good idea and would open the door to type collisions.**

@iSazonov worked on the previous fix, maybe they have some insight into how this behavior is different. My current assumption is the classes are only visible to module scope, but the same is also true for classes defined inside a module, so I'm not 100% sure what the actual underlying differences are.

### Expected behavior

```console
No errors occur and validate set operations work.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
PS> Test-ValidateSet
InvalidOperation: C:\<path-to-modules>\Modules\PSTest\Public\Test-ValidateSet.ps1:6
Line |
   6 |          [ValidateSet([TestValuesGenerator])]
     |          ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | Unable to find type [TestValuesGenerator].
```


### Error details

```console
Exception             :
    Type        : System.Management.Automation.RuntimeException
    ErrorRecord :
        Exception             :
            Type    : System.Management.Automation.ParentContainsErrorRecordException
            Message : Unable to find type [TestValuesGenerator].
            HResult : -2146233087
        TargetObject          : [ValidateSet([TestValuesGenerator])]
        CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: ([ValidateSet([TestValuesGenerator])]:AttributeAst) [], ParentContainsErrorRecordException
        FullyQualifiedErrorId : TypeNotFound
        InvocationInfo        :
            ScriptLineNumber : 6
            OffsetInLine     : 9
            HistoryId        : -1
            ScriptName       : C:\<path-to-modules>\Modules\PSTest\Public\Test-ValidateSet.ps1
            Line             : [ValidateSet([TestValuesGenerator])]

            PositionMessage  : At C:\<path-to-modules>\Modules\PSTest\Public\Test-ValidateSet.ps1:6 char:9
                               +         [ValidateSet([TestValuesGenerator])]
                               +         ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
            PSScriptRoot     : C:\<path-to-modules>\Modules\PSTest\Public
            PSCommandPath    : C:\<path-to-modules>\Modules\PSTest\Public\Test-ValidateSet.ps1
            CommandOrigin    : Internal
        ScriptStackTrace      : at <ScriptBlock>, <No file>: line 1
    TargetSite  :
```

title: Getting error "Unable to find type" when using IValidateSetValuesGenerator in a PowerShell manifest module

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

`Get-Content` (without `-Raw` or `-AsByteStream`) breaks a file into "lines" of `-Encoding` characters which are then sent into the pipeline as individual strings. Set-Content receives strings from the pipeline (or converts the received objects to strings) and saves them as "lines" by appending a new-line marker to each string.

`Get-Content` allows the entire file to be treated as a single string using `-Raw` which ignores new-line markers (as line breaks, just passed literally). This string can then be manipulated with any new-line markers intact (allowing programmatic control of the treatment of `\n` vs `\r\n`, for example) but when saved to a new file using `Set-Content`, the "entire file as single string" then has a new-line marker appended.

I suggest that `Set-Content` should also have a `-Raw` parameter to permit total control of the saved contents. Whether a new-line marker should be placed **between** received strings is a matter for debate but I would suggest not as they can be easily added externally, if desired.

While this behaviour could also be achieved by converting the string to a byte stream (using `[System.Text.Encoding]::(desired encoding value).GetBytes()`) and then specifying `-AsByteStream`, this would be
1. cumbersome
2. performance degrading

Though I have only tested this on 5.1.18362.145, there is no mention of `-Raw` in the documentation through to 7.3. (Not a breaking change since no valid script would currently have this parameter.)


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

`Set-Content -Raw` would concatenate the received strings (or stringified objects) and write this to the file verbatim without any added new-lines.

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

title: Set-Content needs -raw for symmetry with Get-Content

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

If a cmdlet takes a parameter of type `System.DateTime`  a parameter passed to it is parsed using the **local** date format. 
If a function takes a parameter of type `System.DateTime`  a parameter passed to it is parsed using the **Invariant** time format. 

Note this will not be visible if the culture is US.  
For example  
```
ps > set-culture fr-Fr
ps > pwsh -nologo
ps > get-date
mardi 18 janvier 2022 17:57:15

ps > New-TimeSpan -Start "18 janvier 2022" -end "19 janvier 2022" | % days   # French months recognized
1
ps > function test {[cmdletbinding()] param ([system.datetime]$start, [system.datetime]$End) $end.Subtract($start)}
ps > test -Start "18 janvier 2022" -end "19 janvier 2022"
test: Cannot process argument transformation on parameter 'start'. Cannot convert value "18 janvier 2022" to type "System.DateTime". Error: "The string '18 janvier 2022' was not recognized as a valid DateTime. There is an unknown word starting at index '3'."

ps > New-TimeSpan -Start 3/1/2022 -end 1/3/2022 | % days    # parsed as d/m/y 
57
> test  -Start 3/1/2022 -end 1/3/2022 | % days                   # parsed as m/d/y
-57
```
I compiled the cmdlet below and it behaved as the built in cmdlet did. 

```c#
using System;
using System.Management.Automation;

namespace psmodule {
    [Cmdlet(VerbsDiagnostic.Test,"SampleCmdlet")]
    public class TestSampleCmdletCommand : PSCmdlet {
        [Parameter(Position = 0)]
        public DateTime Before { get; set; }
        [Parameter(Position = 1)]
        public DateTime After { get; set; }
        protected override void BeginProcessing()  {}
        protected override void ProcessRecord()    { WriteObject(After.Subtract(Before) ); }
        protected override void EndProcessing()    {}
    }
}
```

**fixing this would be a breaking change** I would like to understand if there is a reason for it. 


### Expected behavior

```console
Consistent. See actual behavior
```


### Actual behavior

```console
ps > New-TimeSpan -Start 3/1/2022 -end 1/3/2022 | % days    # parsed as d/m/y 
57
> test  -Start 3/1/2022 -end 1/3/2022 | % days               # parsed as m/d/y
-57
ps > Test-SampleCmdlet -Before  "18 janvier 2022" -after "19 janvier 2022" | % days  # parsed in French 
1
ps >  test -Start "18 janvier 2022" -end "19 janvier 2022"  # Can only parse English 
<<error janvier isn't recognized>>
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value[0m
----                           -----[0m
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0ÔÇª}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

(same on 5.1.19041.1320)
```


### Visuals

_No response_

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

The following script, which should creates a Service Principal in Azure and assigns it a given Azure AD role, fails in the last step, precisely when assigning the role to the service principal. 

```
<#
param (
  [Parameter(Mandatory = $True)]
  [string]$tenantId,

  [Parameter(Mandatory = $True)]
  [string]$spName,

  [Parameter(Mandatory = $True)]
  [string]$role
)

Connect-AzureAD -TenantId $tenantId

# Create the Azure AD Application Registration
$appRegistration = New-AzureADApplication -DisplayName $spName

# Create the Service Principal
New-AzureADServicePrincipal -AppId $appRegistration.AppId

# Get the role object from the given role name
$AdminRoleObject = Get-AzureADDirectoryRole | Where-Object {$_.DisplayName -eq $role}

# Assign the role to the app registration
Add-AzureADDirectoryRoleMember -ObjectId $AdminRoleObject.ObjectId -RefObjectId $appRegistration.ObjectId
```


### Expected behavior

```console
The service principal is created in Azure AD, and has the given Azure AD role assigned to it
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The service principal is created in Azure AD, but the script fails the Azure AD role assignment. By observing the error message, it seems that an extra '/' is added to the URL, like in the following: https://graph.windows.net//
```


### Error details

```console
Add-AzureADDirectoryRoleMember: Error occurred while executing AddDirectoryRoleMember 
Code: Request_BadRequest
Message: The URI 'https://graph.windows.net//xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx/directoryObjects/xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx' is not valid since it is not based on 'https://graph.windows.net/xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx-xxx/'.
RequestId: ce7e548a-642a-4998-a153-910671c812ee
```

### Steps to reproduce

2. update pwsh from 7.2.0 to 7.2.1 manually, i.e. installing pwsh v7.2.1 to overwrite v7.2.0
3. delete directory 'C:\Windows\System32\PowerShell\7.2.0' manually
4. run `Unregister-PSSessionConfiguration PowerShell.7`
5. run `winrm invoke Restore http://schemas.microsoft.com/wbem/wsman/1/config/plugin '@{}'`
6. run `Enable-PSRemoting` in pwsh v7.2.1 and re-config winrm to listen to HTTPS.
7. run 
    ```
    New-PSSession -cn . -Port xxx -UseSSL -ConfigurationName Powershell.7
    ```

p.s. 

1. sorry for that i've forgotten the order between step 3&4. 
2. everything is fine before pwsh v7.2.1. after updating to v7.2.1, step 3-4 messed up winrm. i tried to repair that via step 5 according to error info of `Get-PSSessionConfiguration`.

```console
all pssession stuff runs in background and no black window pops up.
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Search the existing issues.

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Hello All,

I am experiencing a error when writing csv data to an sql table with PowerShell.  The data will start to write and display an increasing percentage but it will stop abruptly and return:

Write-SqlTableData:
Line |
  21 |  Write-SqlTableData -InputData $b -DatabaseName DATABASE -TableName  …
     |  ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | Timeout expired.  The timeout period elapsed prior to completion of the operation or the server is not responding.

The csv is just under 1,000,000 rows.


### Expected behavior

```console
I am using the connection below:

$ServerName = "SERVER"
$DatabaseName = "DATABASE"
$Query = ""
$QueryTimeout = 0
$ConnectionTimeout = 0
$conn=New-Object System.Data.SqlClient.SQLConnection
$ConnectionString = "Server={0};Database={1};Integrated Security=True;Connect Timeout={2}" -f $ServerName,$DatabaseName,$ConnectionTimeout
$conn.ConnectionString=$ConnectionString
$conn.Open()
$cmd=New-Object system.Data.SqlClient.SqlCommand($Query,$conn)
$cmd.CommandTimeout=$QueryTimeout
$ds=New-Object system.Data.DataSet
Clear-Host;
$da=New-Object system.Data.SqlClient.SqlDataAdapter($cmd)
[void]$da.fill($ds)
$conn.Close()

Both $QueryTimeout = 0 and $ConnectionTimeout = 0 are set to zero. Also, SSMS Execution time out is set to zero.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
It will attempt to write the csv file but will end up producing error: Write-SqlTableData : Execution Timeout Expired.  The timeout period elapsed prior to completion of the operation or the server is not responding.
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Hi,

the fact that PowerShell functions "automatically" return any and all objects to the pipeline is a surprise factor for many people coming from other languages, but I totally get the intent and sometimes it can be a neat feature.

However, for other functions and usecases it only makes things harder.
It can be a frustrating experience to go through every line of code and ensure with hyper-vigilance that absolutely no cmdlet or method called may clog the pipeline with undesired objects and thus throw off the calling code by displacing the expected object or array of objects. You basically want to prepend `$null = ` to every line to make sure stuff doesn't break.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

I propose a function decorator / attribute such as:

```powershell
function Invoke-MyFunction {
    [CmdletBinding()]
    [PipelineOutput(Mode = 'Explicit')]

    $DATA = Get-ChildItem $env:SystemDrive

    # Oops, I poisoned the pipeline!
    $DATA

    # I know System.Collections.ArrayList is deprecated and I don't use it in actual code,
    # but this is a "classic" example of a method that produces unexpected output for many people
    [System.Collections.ArrayList]::new().add('OH NO NOT AGAIN')

    return @(0, $DATA)
}
```

that the user can add to functions where "leaking" objects to the pipeline is undesired and total control is a better and more robust approach. Only objects explicitly returned to the pipeline with `return` will be sent on, anything "implicitly returned" will be discarded.

Thoughts?

labels.description: The issue is a duplicate.
labels.name: Resolution-Duplicate

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

title: Add advanced function attribute to not "leak" data to the pipeline unless explicitly returned with `return` keyword

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16737

Currently, the file & folder UnixMode of powershell has no numeric Property, user must write a script to calculate it by himself.


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Property name is "LinuxNumber" or "Number"

Don't forget SGID, SUID and sticky bit, eg:
1777

When listing a directory, Property may not be displayed by default, but are displayed when format-list.

### Steps to reproduce

I have a Powershell script with embedded C# code. 

Being used to use the more compact "`function {`" programming convention for curly braces, I modified it by **only** moving `{` from below to next after the function name, like this:
```Powershell
Set-StrictMode -Version Latest
$ErrorActionPreference = 'Stop'
$CSharpCode = @'
...

public static SafeFileHandle GetConIn() {
    SafeFileHandle fileHandle = CreateFileW("CONIN$", GENERIC_READ, FILE_SHARE_READ, IntPtr.Zero, OPEN_EXISTING, 0, IntPtr.Zero);
    if (fileHandle.IsInvalid)
    {
        throw new System.ComponentModel.Win32Exception();
    }
    return fileHandle;
}
...
}
'@

$NativeMethods = Add-Type -Language CSharp -MemberDefinition $CSharpCode -Name NativeMethods -Namespace Console -PassThru -UsingNamespace 'Microsoft.Win32.SafeHandles' -ErrorAction SilentlyContinue
if (-not $NativeMethods) { throw "Fatal error: Unable to compile the necessary C# code." }

```

The script then fails with: 
```powershell
 $ .\get_console_mode_gist.ps1

Line |
  39 |  … veMethods = Add-Type -Language CSharp -MemberDefinition $CSharpCode - …
     |                ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
     | Cannot add type. Compilation errors occurred.
```


### Expected behavior

```console
To not make a difference on where I put my `{}`'s.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Fails due to placement of the `{}`s.
```

### Steps to reproduce

I found this on Twitter: https://twitter.com/pronichkin/status/1476063320822419458
Steps:
1. Try to run this: `Test-WSMan -ComputerName Whatever -CertificateThumbprint Whatever -Authentication ClientCertificate`
2. Note the failure to bind CertificateThumbprint
3. Move `CertificateThumbprint` so it's the last parameter, like this: `Test-WSMan -ComputerName Whatever -Authentication ClientCertificate -CertificateThumbprint Whatever` and try again
4. Note how it succeeds

The issue appears to be that the setter for `CertificateThumbprint` does some validation and assumes other properties have been set when it is getting bound. This works fine for the other wsman cmdlets because their default value for AuthenticationMechanism is set to Default, but Test-Wsman uses None by default.

The check is done here: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/Microsoft.WSMan.Management/WsManHelper.cs#L636
The default value is set here: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/src/Microsoft.WSMan.Management/PingWSMan.cs#L90

```console
The cmdlet works regardless of the parameter binding order
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Test-WSMan: Cannot bind parameter 'CertificateThumbprint' to the target. Exception setting "CertificateThumbprint": "A CertificateThumbPrint cannot be specified when None is specified."
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Get-DscResource doesn't show class-based DSC resources if the PSD1 has all of these CmdletsToExport, FunctionsToExport, AliasesToExport. To mitigate the issues, one of them has to be commented. 
This is a bug introduced during the PowerShell performance related changes. Andrew Menagarishvili has looked into the code and confirmed this bug.

### Expected behavior

```console
Get-DscResources should return DSC resources
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Get-DscResource doesn't show the DSC resource
```


### Error details

```console
No error.
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Observed with OpenSSH V7.1+.
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23668037/149572559-14173960-4dd6-42b3-b236-e5d3fb80b1ce.png)

With workaround by commenting functionsToExport, Get-DscResource shows the class-based DSC Resource

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23668037/149572537-92abd5e1-0747-40a9-9285-f0ddb41bfeb6.png)

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

It would be nice to be able to execute commands like:

```powershell
rm --rec --force ~/somedir
```

the only difference in this command vs. one that currently works, is that parameter names start with a double dash `--` instead of a single dash `-`.

In this case, this same command is compatible with Linux (but not macOS unfortunately.)

Related: #6397

Here is one possible (slightly contrived) use-case in case you are wondering why anyone would want this:

```powershell
$servers = 'winserver','linuxserver','otherlinuxserver'

foreach ($server in $servers) {
    ssh $server -- rm --rec --force ~/some/path
    ...
}
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

title: PredictionResult Type Load Exception on starting PS in Windows Terminal

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

As a user I want to configure my powershell profile to exclude completion from certain modules that I'm not using on a given context. For example, as a developer when I'm on a powershell session and type `Remove-I` for (remove-item) the first result I get on autocompletion is `Remove-InitiatorId`. 

In many scenarios like these, some commands that won't ever be used in this context lead to a poor experience where you need to either type more characters to disambiguate or tab through. 

It's great that by default you can get commands from all installed modules for discoverability, but with the growing number of modules it becomes painful to use on a regular session.

To provide an analogy, this is similar to importing all namespaces by default on C#, each type is readily available, but searching through the types becomes much more problematic because they are way more irrelevant types in scope.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Ideally this would be either an allow list or a block list (possibly an allow list), where you can set your preferences for the session via a cmd-let to filter completions to the modules you've defined.

`Set-CommandCompletion Microsoft.PowerShell.Utility, Microsoft.PowerShell.Management`

That will make only commands in those modules to be considered for completions and you can put this on your $Profile so that it happens every time you create a new session.

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

body: # PR Summary Let the macOS installer can run without Rosetta on Apple Silicon. ## PR Context This patch makes the macOS installer (_powershell-\*-osx-arm64.pkg_) able to run without [Rosetta] on Apple Silicon (e.g., M1, M1 Pro, M1 Max). Although the executable binary (*pwsh*) in itself already natively runs on Apple Silicon, the installer for it still requires Rosetta (as of 7.3.0-preview.1): I fixed it by specifying the proper `hostArchitectures` to the `installer-gui-script` configuration. (In PowerShell's packaging script, the template for it is placed in *tools/packaging/packaging.strings.psd1*.) The solution was inspired by fish's fix commit: . Fixes . [Rosetta]: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rosetta_(software)#Rosetta_2 ## PR Checklist - [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission) - body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

I can't find this with a search but that may be searching for the wrong thing.

I had a task where the most sensible way to compare two lumps of text was with `diff.exe`  - I'm using the version which is installed with git for convenience -  my script worked in the  PowerShell Integrated Console in VSCode, but anywhere else  I'd see output like this    
` ←[31m  Text that should be read ←[0m`

That is: **an arrow character was printed where there should be an "Escape", and the escape sequence was not processed** 

by a process of trial and error I established 
```
<<path>>\diff.exe --help ; $y = "`e[31m Red Text `e[0m"; $Y
``` 
Would output  correctly  but 
```
$x =<<path>>\diff.exe --help ; $y = "`e[31m Red Text `e[0m"; $Y
``` 
Would render escape as arrow, but $y and  it would render correctly in a subsequent command .  Output is only corrupted while the command that contains diff.exe is running.   The same behaviour occurred  with   `diff.exe <<params>> | pscmdlet` or `[void](diff.exe <<params>>)` anything which stopped the main output going to the console.  However `git diff` commands don't suffer from the error. `$x = git diff head~1 ; $x = git diff head~1 ;` 


I found two workarounds 
1.  run `Cmd.exe <<path to diff>>  <<params>>   > tempfile`
2. Use `Start-Process -wait -WindowStyle Hidden  -RedirectStandardOutput $diffOutput -FilePath $PathToDiff -ArgumentList  <<params>>`

Note that in the start-process example, If  `-NoNewWindow` is used instead of `-WindowStyle Hidden` the problem returns

The mechanism of the corruption isn't clear but the something seems to bypassing standard output and impact the console for the duration of that command- whether it is possible for PowerShell to trap it is also not clear. 
Nor is it clear how common this problem is:  it's possible that diff does something unique, or there may be dozens of cases waiting to be discovered. As more people are coming to pwsh from the Linux world and wanting to bring tools they know, AND use of ansi formatting is getting less niche and more mainstream those cases will emerge - if they are there 




### Expected behavior

```console
$x =<<path>\diff.exe --help ; $y = "`e[31m Red Text `e[0m"; $Y

Stores the help from diff in $x, and prints "Red Text" in red.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
$x =<<path>\diff.exe --help ; $y = "`e[31m Red Text `e[0m"; $Y

Stores the help from diff in $x, and prints "←[31m Red Text ←[0m" 
However if $y is entered as the next command it prints as a red text. (Commands in the same PS1 file behave like commands joined with ";"  )
```


### Error details

```console
No errors
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value[0m
----                           -----[0m
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19042
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0ΓÇª}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/16209593/149323431-5d2ec03a-c3b2-4628-a678-405418bc8cc2.png)
title: External application leaks something ANSI-Corrupting into PowerShell session

body:
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16330

<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary

Runtime updates in #16309 broke `Start-PSBootbootstrap` on Windows PowerShell 5.1 by introducing a hard dependency on the `[SemanticVersion]` type, introduced in 6.0.

This commit replaces the type reference with a PowerShell class that implements the necessary subset of functionality (namely `IComparable`) from `[SemanticVersion]` needed for sorting SDK versions, ostensibly the motivation for introducing this dependency in the first place.

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

## PR Context

I, like many others, have been building PowerShell >=6 from source with Windows PowerShell 5.1 for years and still occassionally do. Having to manually patch `build.psm1` everytime I want to bootstrap a build from WPS is frustrating. Hence this PR.

title: UnixMode + UnixStat.Mode

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Currently, Set-StrictMode -Version accepts "latest" to indicate the most recent version of StrictMode. It would be beneficial to also accept "off" and remove the Set-StrictMode -Off option. The "off" option would turn StrictMode to version 0.0

Usage: Set-StrictMode -Version off


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

Invoke-Command -StrictMode allows "off" as a parameter.
Refer to this pull request https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/16545#discussion_r782709242

title: Update change log to remove the broken URL

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

# PR Summary
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/3082
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16676
Fixes https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/13525

Adds support for Type aliases. Normal types, generic types and array types are all supported. Example:
```
using type MyNormalType = System.Collections.ArrayList
using type MyGenericType = System.Collections.Generic.Dictionary[string,int]
using type MyMultiDimArray = int[,]
using type MyOpenGenericType = System.Collections.Generic.List
[MyNormalType]
[MyGenericType]
[MyMultiDimArray]
[MyOpenGenericType[string]]
```
Also adds support for Namespace aliases. Example:
```
using namespace SMA = System.Management.Automation
[SMA.PowerShell]
```
Naturally, the tab completion has been updated to support these alias features.

There are also some other changes that were made to better support these features:

**Duplicate using namespaces are blocked at parse time.** Previously they were allowed, but caused runtime errors if you attempted to use the short type name from the duplicated namespace. See: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/13525  
This is not technically required because the check could be limited to just namespace aliases, but seems unlikely to cause issues.

**The public Alias property for UsingStatementAst was changed from StringConstantExpressionAst to Ast.** This was done to allow the use of TypeConstraintAst for namespace and type aliases.  
This is not technically required because the text can simply be parsed again to get the itypename where its needed but that's not ideal.

**The tokenflags for both the name and alias tokens when using type aliases are changed to TypeName** for better syntax highlighting and tab completion.

**The parsing rules for the alias definition uses type rules for Type/Namespace instead of generic.** This was done for better tokenization.

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

## PR Context
I saw the code from @IISResetMe here: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/pull/8968 and thought it was a shame to just let it die like that.  
I wouldn't have known how to do this without having his code as a starting point so most of the credit should go to him.
<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

### Prerequisites

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Run this script in PowerShell 7.2.1:
https://superuser.com/a/1293303/298707

````
[CmdletBinding()] Param (
    [Parameter(Mandatory=$true)][ValidateSet('Off', 'On')][string]$BluetoothStatus
)
If ((Get-Service bthserv).Status -eq 'Stopped') { Start-Service bthserv }
Add-Type -AssemblyName System.Runtime.WindowsRuntime
$asTaskGeneric = ([System.WindowsRuntimeSystemExtensions].GetMethods() | ? { $_.Name -eq 'AsTask' -and $_.GetParameters().Count -eq 1 -and $_.GetParameters()[0].ParameterType.Name -eq 'IAsyncOperation`1' })[0]
Function Await($WinRtTask, $ResultType) {
    $asTask = $asTaskGeneric.MakeGenericMethod($ResultType)
    $netTask = $asTask.Invoke($null, @($WinRtTask))
    $netTask.Wait(-1) | Out-Null
````

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

`PowerShell Core` should be renamed to `UltraShell`, otherwise it's mistaken with `Windows PowerShell`. Since this project is not an update of the other (with full retro-compatibility) they shouldn't be called the same. It's a sort of impersonation and I feel is misleading for the non techie user. In fact I know most people is not aware they are different programs.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Implementing the `IList` interface to the [Range Operator](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_operators?view=powershell-7.2#range-operator-) would (presumably) require a easier syntax in case it is used for a (non-pipeline) parameter.

```PowerShell
$Table = @'
1,6,6,2,9,4
8,4,3,9,5,7
1,0,9,5,4,0
'@
```

Currently it is required to used the [Array subexpression operator `@( )`](https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.core/about/about_operators?view=powershell-7.2#array-subexpression-operator--) to use a range as argument:

```PowerShell
ConvertFrom-Csv $Table -Header @('a'..'f') 
```

With the `IList` interface implemented, I expect the syntax to be simplified to:
```PowerShell
ConvertFrom-Csv $Table -Header 'a'..'f'
```

Related StackOverflow question/answer: [OrderedDictionary key name at specified index](https://stackoverflow.com/a/70618275/1701026)

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

labels.description: parser, language semantics
labels.name: WG-Language

title: Add `IList` interface to the Range Operator

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Currently, when Get-ChildItem returns a file size, it's in bytes—even if the size is several terabytes.  bash lets users specify the `-h` switch to ls.  In Powershell, it's more complex as Get-ChildItem doesn't know anything about the data.  Adding the switch would cause the method to prefer human readable sizes.  The switch would look for a property named `Length` and replace that in the select with `LengthAsStr` (if that exists in the class) which would be assumed to be human readable.

The second step would be to arrange with the authors of `System.Io.FileInfo` and `System.Io.DirectoryInfo` to add `LengthAsStr`.

I considered saying that Get-ChildItem itself could attempt to convert the field, but `Length` might be in something other than bytes, say characters.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

(Oversimplifying) `System.ConsoleColor` defines 8 "regular" colors and 8 corresponding "dark" colors, e.g. `Yellow` and `DarkYellow`.

The same 16 colors are represented in `$PSStyle` members as 8 "regular" colors and 8 corresponding "bright" colors, e.g. `Yellow` and `BrightYellow`.

`System.ConsoleColor`'s `DarkYellow` is `$PSStyle`'s `Yellow`, and `System.ConsoleColor`'s `Yellow` is `$PSStyle`'s `BrightYellow`.

This is confusing to say the least, and should probably be made consistent.

### Expected behavior

I would expect `System.ConsoleColor`'s `Yellow` and `$PSStyle`'s `Yellow` to be the same color.

### Actual behavior

`System.ConsoleColor`'s `DarkYellow` is `$PSStyle`'s `Yellow`, and `System.ConsoleColor`'s `Yellow` is `$PSStyle`'s `BrightYellow`.

### Error details

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

It would be great to have built-in support for easy access to unicode items using short codes.


### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

The new `$PSStyle` variable is great and there could be something similar like `$PSEmoji` for common Emojis and maybe even a selected source of other Unicode letters in `$PSUnicode`.

Short codes for Emojis shall be based on existing GitHub short codes and could be based on the [GitHub Emoji API](https://api.github.com/emojis) together with [Unicode Full Emoji List](https://unicode.org/emoji/charts/full-emoji-list.html), similar to what is implemented by @ikatyang in his [Emoji Cheat Sheet](https://github.com/ikatyang/emoji-cheat-sheet/).

labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

### Steps to reproduce

When response from the utiliser of PowerShell has been necessary, PowerShell has responded automatically without failure after invocation of "START-TRANSCRIPT -APPEND -NOCLOBBER -INCLUDEINVOCATIONHEADER".

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Run the following script in Windows Terminal:

```
& {
    for ($i = 5; $i -gt 0; $i–-) {
        Write-Progress -Activity "Launching rocket" -SecondsRemaining $i
        Start-Sleep 1
        dotnet --version
    }
    
    Write-Host "Output messed up!" -Fore Yellow
}
```

### Expected behavior

```console
The output from PowerShell and native command gets displayed in order.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
The output is messed up.

I believe it's because we save the cursor position before doing progress rendering, then the cursor position was changed by the native command, but when completing the progress rendering, we reset the cursor position back to the saved value.
```


### Error details

```console
N/A
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.0
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.0
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

The default format for `gci` looks terrible, it looks much better as `gci | ft -autosize`, I will post a few screenshots here.

This is `gci` on my Windows system:

![gci on Windows](https://i.imgur.com/3WgxsoE.png)

This is `gci | ft -autosize` on my Windows system:

![gci with ft -autosize on Windows](https://i.imgur.com/jsu97gM.png)

This is `gci` on my Linux system, this is especially horrible, I can't even see the file names!

![gci on Linux](https://i.imgur.com/M30Xy4X.png)

This is `gci | ft -autosize` on my Linux system, it looks pretty good, not quite as good as `ls --color=auto -lh`, but close, your color selections are also less than ideal (especially for directories.)

![gci | ft -autosize on Linux](https://i.imgur.com/ussV2Su.png)

this is the top part with directories, to show you what I mean about the colors:

![gci | ft -autosize on Linux (directories)](https://i.imgur.com/K8rIw2A.jpg)

this `ls --color=auto -lh` output on my Linux system for comparison (GNU coreutils ls of course):

![ls -lh output on Linux](https://i.imgur.com/dqnXXjf.jpg)

and here is `ls --color=auto` output:

![ls output on Linux](https://i.imgur.com/yARZqtD.png)

for a couple more comparisons, here is `lsd -lh`:

![lsd -lh on Linux](https://i.imgur.com/Lj8BsZr.png)

and here is `lsd`:

![lsd on Linux](https://i.imgur.com/cp0ZBse.png)

and here is `exa -lh`:

![exa -lh on Linux](https://i.imgur.com/07TO9Fg.png)

and here is `exa`:

![exa on Linux](https://i.imgur.com/ohKZOcq.png)

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

If using an autosize format for File/Dir info has negative implications like performance, it should still be possible to make a compact format with fixed widths for just about all the fields except name. Name would be the last field and can wrap. In case e.g. a username or length is too long, it could be truncated.

A lot can be said about file listing presentation, and this is not a strong point for this project.

The default format on Windows is OK. I like the autosize format better, but the default works more or less.

On Linux the default format is unusable at smaller widths because there are two extra columns for user and group with an unnecessarily huge amount of spacing. I suppose you did this to make listing closer to things like `ls -l` on Linux, but on Windows you do not show ACL/owner information in file listings, and for most of the work users do on Linux, they do not need this information either. Which is why they generally just use `ls` and not `ls -l`.

`gci -n` is closer to how `ls` works, actually closer to how `ls -1` works, but then you don't get the colors.

The permission bits are also generally not very interesting. On Windows the attributes column shows useful information like whether the filesystem object is a directory or readonly etc.. So why not have an attributes column on Linux with actually useful indicators of some sort? And hide the user/group columns?

But this is a digression.

This issue is specifically about the column spacing.

You will probably say "override the format", and I will definitely do that, even though that's not particularly pleasant to do and involves XML files etc.. But I am opening this issue about the default experience for users.

You might say "make your own function", this is also extremely unpleasant, because I cannot make a function that has all of the completion magic of `gci` without doing a lot of really horrible things. Also if I make a function that just pipes to `ft -autosize` it will destroy the objects and I would not be able to use it in pipelines.

labels.description: Issue has been identified as a bug in the product
labels.name: Issue-Bug

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

title: Make default gci/gi output more like "gci | ft -autosize"

body:
<!-- Anything that looks like this is a comment and can't be seen after the Pull Request is created. -->

This PR adds SBOM manifests for created nuget packages for coordinated package builds.

<!-- Summarize your PR between here and the checklist. -->

SBOM manifests are added by splitting the existing `New-ILNugetPacakge` function, which creates all nuget packages at once, into `New-ILNugetPackageSource` and `New-ILNugetPackageFromSource` functions.  These new functions create source and package for just one file at a time, so that an SBOM manifest can be created (via yml template) for each file/package.

<!-- Provide a little reasoning as to why this Pull Request helps and why you have opened it. -->

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

On a rather large subtree on an even larger disk, I'm encountering the following error:

````
PS❯  Get-ChildItem -File -Force -Recurse -LiteralPath 'J:\<REDACTED>.20211120\C\' | % { $_.FullName} | Out-File c:/tmp/allfiles_ps_fullnames.txt
Get-ChildItem: The system cannot find the file specified.
````

with both 7.2.1 and 7.3.0-preview.1.

Enumerating the same tree in `CMD` using `DIR /S /B /A-D J:\<REDACTED>.20211120\C` returns 519,834 files (and no error). The aforementioned incomplete PowerShell output has 152,415 entries.

The same pipeline also fails in Windows PowerShell 5.1:

````
PS❯  Get-ChildItem -File -Force -Recurse -LiteralPath 'J:\<REDACTED>.20211120\C\' | % { $_.FullName} | Out-File c:/tmp/allfiles_wps51_fullnames.txt
The script failed due to call depth overflow.
At line:1 char:1
+ Get-ChildItem -File -Force -Recurse -LiteralPath 'J:\<REDACTED>.20211120 ...
+ ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : InvalidOperation: (0:Int32) [], RuntimeException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : CallDepthOverflow
````

`Get-Error` suggests something symlink/junction-related, but doesn't indicate the offending item(s).

Process Monitor didn't give me any clue (no "not found" error there).

### Expected behavior

```console
The entire tree should be enumerated.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Enumeration fails somewhere during the recursive scan.
```

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I would like to be able to do:

```powershell
1,2,3,4,5,6 | % -contains 3

# instead of

(1,2,3,4,5,6) -contains 3
```

this would be different from the already proposed single value operation of `Where-Object` in that, it would operate on the entire collection instead of each single value, e.g.:

```powershell
'foobarbaz','quux' | ? -match 'bar'
# 'foobarbaz'

'foo','bar','baz' | % -contains 'bar'
# True
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Things like `sed` allow you to do things like this:

```powershell
write 'X X X X' | sed 's/X/Y/2'
# X Y X X
```

pwsh could also do things like:

```powershell
'X X X X' -replace 'X','Y',2
# X Y X X
```

just as an example, this may not be how you'd implement this specific option, but in general, any parameters starting at the third position for `-replace` or e.g. the second position for `-match` could be flags/options to modify the operation. They wouldn't have to be a single string, they could be a list.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Add `Format` parameter to `Get-Clipboard` cmdlet. Like it done in Windows PowerShell. For example:
```
$img = Get-Clipboard -Format Image
$img.Save("$PWD\file.png")
```
I am understanding that this can be done using .Net methods, but `Format` parameter make life better.
`TextFormatData` makes too.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

```
Get-Clipboard
    -Format Text, FileDropList, Image, Audio                              Named
    -TextFormatData Text, UnicodeText, Rtf, Html, CommaSeparatedValue     Named
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Console output truncated with an ellipsis causes remaining text to shift to the left when using $PSStyle

I have a .ps1xml format file that defines a view for file and directory objects which uses $PSStyle to highlight parts of the output, e.g.:
```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="utf-8"?>
<Configuration>
    <SelectionSets>
        <SelectionSet>
            <Name>FileSystemTypes</Name>
            <Types>
                <TypeName>System.IO.DirectoryInfo</TypeName>
                <TypeName>System.IO.FileInfo</TypeName>
            </Types>
        </SelectionSet>
    </SelectionSets>
    <ViewDefinitions>
        <View>
            <Name>children</Name>
            <ViewSelectedBy>
                <SelectionSetName>FileSystemTypes</SelectionSetName>
            </ViewSelectedBy>
            <TableControl>
                <TableHeaders>
                    <TableColumnHeader> <Label>Name</Label>                <Width>30</Width>  <Alignment>Left</Alignment>  </TableColumnHeader>
                    <TableColumnHeader> <Label>LastWriteTime      </Label> <Width>19</Width>  <Alignment>Left</Alignment>  </TableColumnHeader>
                    <TableColumnHeader> <Label>Size      </Label>          <Width>10</Width>  <Alignment>Right</Alignment> </TableColumnHeader>
                    <TableColumnHeader> <Label>FullName</Label>                               <Alignment>Left</Alignment>  </TableColumnHeader>
                </TableHeaders>
                <TableRowEntries>
                    <TableRowEntry>
                        <TableColumnItems>
                            <TableColumnItem>
                                <ScriptBlock>
                                    "$($PSStyle.Reverse)$($_.Name)$($PSStyle.Reset)"
                                </ScriptBlock>
                            </TableColumnItem>
                            <TableColumnItem>
                                <ScriptBlock>
                                    $_.LastWriteTime.ToString('yyyy-MM-dd HH:mm:ss')
                                </ScriptBlock>
                            </TableColumnItem>
                            <TableColumnItem>
                                <ScriptBlock>
                                    ($_.Length/1MB).ToString('0.000')+' MB'
                                </ScriptBlock>
                            </TableColumnItem>
                            <TableColumnItem>
                                <ScriptBlock>
                                    $_.FullName
                                </ScriptBlock>
                            </TableColumnItem>
                        </TableColumnItems>
                    </TableRowEntry>
                </TableRowEntries>
            </TableControl>
        </View>
    </ViewDefinitions>
</Configuration>
```

```
$filePath = 'D:\my.format.ps1xml'
Update-FormatData -PrependPath $filePath
Get-ChildItem -Path $PSHOME -File
```

When the `Name` column contains a long file name, the console truncates the name and adds an ellipsis `…` to indicate that there are truncated characters. When this happens, the remaining characters on the line are shifted 3 spaces to the left:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23632110/148135987-1eda7e9e-0812-4a79-8a39-2a39e8486e17.png)

Removing the references to $PSStyle in the .ps1xml format file gives the expected layout:
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23632110/148136016-60c7f6ab-2c22-487e-bd1a-314f2669be9b.png)

The shift effect is present for any value of $PSStyle.OutputRendering.



### Expected behavior

```console
Output text on lines with a truncation ellipsis should remain aligned with its column header.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Output text on lines with a truncation ellipsis is shifted to the left.
```


### Error details

```console
n/a
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.name: Issue-Bug

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: Console output truncated with an ellipsis causes remaining text to shift to the left when using $PSStyle

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

I'd like to be able to write an extension for Powershell that is able to read the current REPL input line and history in order to provide further user-friendly drop-downs or other code suggestions while the user is editing the line.

The reason for such API is that a future extension should **not** require the user to launch a separate piece of software terminal application but should be available right away whenever the user opens any kind of PowerShell terminal (native, Core, VSCode etc.).

For example, I'd like to be able to provide parameter suggestions for the `dotnet` CLI command.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

After the proposed API has been created and established for PowerShell, in order for an extension author to write an extension, the extension author should be required to create a library project in .NET (Core) and implement a `PowerShellReplExtension` interface (to be established).

Then, after the extension has been compiled, the resulting .NET (Core) `.dll` file should be deployed by just writing the resulting .NET (Core) `.dll` file (and its dependency files) to a sub folder of a common PowerShell extension container folder, like `~\AppData\Local\PowerShell\Extensions\REPL\`.

Whenever a PowerShell session is started, PowerShell should browse the `~\AppData\Local\PowerShell\Extensions\REPL\` folder for any existing extension (i.e. classes that implement the proposed `PowerShellReplExtension` interface) and trigger those extensions with every user keyboard input. The extensions are then supposed to update the console as required.

Probably a manifest file may be required to be stored in `~\AppData\Local\PowerShell\Extensions\REPL\` for determining the sequence of extensions called. And there may be a `handled` flag, supposed to be initially set to `false` with every user key stroke and then passed along the extensions which may set this flag to `true` once the first extension has updated the console accordingly.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Calling [System.IO.File]::WriteAllBytes appears to use the directory the shell was opened at, not the current directory.

Repro:
Open the shell in <dir1>
Set-Location to <dir2>
Call [System.IO.File]::WriteAllBytes("some_valid_folder_in_dir2\file", $Byte)


### Expected behavior

```console
$Byte gets written to <dir2>\some_valid_folder_in_dir2\file
```


### Actual behavior

```console
MethodInvocationException: Exception calling "WriteAllBytes" with "2" argument(s): "Could not find a part of the path '<dir1>\some_valid_folder_in_dir2\file'."
```


### Error details

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

1. Run the PowerShell 7.2.1 MSI installer, for example PowerShell-7.2.1-win-x64.msi from the releases page on GitHub
2. Step through the wizard until the _Use Microsoft Update to help keep your computer secure and up to date_ page.
3. Click the _See the Microsoft Update FAQ_ link.

### Expected behavior

The PowerShell installer should link to a valid Microsoft Update FAQ page, or at least not show a link to an invalid page.


### Actual behavior

The link points to https://aka.ms/PowerShell-Microsoft-Update-FAQ which redirects via https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=57191, https://update.microsoft.com/microsoftupdate/v6/vistaabout.aspx, and https://www.update.microsoft.com/microsoftupdate/v6/vistaabout.aspx to https://fe2.update.microsoft.com/microsoftupdate/v6/vistaabout.aspx. This page uses a certificate signed by the Microsoft Update Secure Server CA 2.1, which is not trusted in any modern browsers.

### Additional issues

this link has the same issue:
https://go.microsoft.com/fwlink/?LinkID=57190

### Visuals

![PowerShell 7.2.1 installation wizard page with link to Microsoft Update FAQ](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/984760/148075089-ead086c6-367b-409a-a386-2f93dee7fd78.png)

![Microsoft Edge showing a certificate issue for the Microsoft Update FAQ page](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/984760/148075201-336fe556-e6c2-4304-9f84-5bdcb1817273.png)

labels.description: specific to affecting the build

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When using the Get-ChildItem cmdlet, I would expect -File to filter for only files, and when using -Exclude, these files should be possible to further filter. Instead when using the -File and the -Exclude parameters, no files are returned.

The problem is only reproducable with the -File parameter, not the -Directory parameter.

### Expected behavior

```console
Given a folder with files "a" and "b", and a folder "subfolder":

If using `Get-ChildItem -File`: Both files should be returned, and the subFolder should not be returned.
If using `Get-ChildItem -Exclude "a"`: File "b" and folder "subFolder" should be returned
If using `Get-ChildItem -File -Exclude "a"`: Only file "b" should be returned
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Given a folder with files "a" and "b", and a folder "subfolder":

If using `Get-ChildItem -File`: Both files are returned, the subFolder should not be returned.
If using `Get-ChildItem -Exclude "a"`: File "b" and folder "subFolder" should be returned

However:
If using `Get-ChildItem -File -Exclude "a"`: No files nor folders are returned.
```


### Error details

```console
No errors are returned
```

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.

- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Hello,
I am using `get-date -UFormat "%V-%b-%Y"` in Windows. 
And the output is **1-Jan-2022**

I am using the same command in Linux as well
`date +"%V-%b-%Y"`
And the output is **01-Jan-2022**

%V for the week number.


As you can see, the output in Windows differs from the output in Linux.

From what i understood on https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/powershell/module/microsoft.powershell.utility/get-date?view=powershell-7.2 , `-UFormat` should "Displays the date and time in UNIX format." , but it does not.



The problem is that I am using a script in Linux which generates a file with the week number, then a script in Powershell that copies the file on the local machine.

And, because if this difference in the output ( missing 0 in the windows command ), the script fails.



Thank you

### Expected behavior

```console
get-date -UFormat "%V-%b-%Y"
01-Jan-2022
```


### Actual behavior

```console

1-Jan-2022
```

### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

When I open a new terminal window/tab, I like my shell to display a random quote. In `zsh`, I do this by running `fortune` from inside my `.zshrc` file. But I **don't** want my shell to output a random quote when it's being run in some other (non-login shell) context. In `zsh`, you can do this by checking the `login` option:

```zsh
if [[ -o login ]]; then
    fortune
fi
```

Similarly, you can test `-o interactive` to see if `zsh` is running interactively or not.

PowerShell has a `-Login` parameter, but it doesn't appear to be an intuitive way to check for it from within my `Microsoft.PowerShell_profile.ps1` file.

It's also not clear how to check to see if PowerShell is running interactively. There's `[Environment]::UserInteractive`, but I can't tell if that's the right thing to check or not.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

### Steps to reproduce

Simply running `Get-Volume` is all that's required to reproduce the problem.  The first time the command is issued, $null is returned.  Subsequent requests work OK until PowerShell is not used for a while, and then the issue appears again.

I have many drives on my system (at least 5 and often more if external backup drives are connected).  I'm not sure if this is a factory.

The problem did not seem to occur on the 7.0.6 release which I used for a very long time.  I recently moved to the 7.2.x releases and the problem appeared and is something I have to workaround in all my scripts or it affects my work daily.

### Steps to reproduce

While attempting to download a file from the following URL, invoke-webrequest hangs seemingly indefinitely with no indication of why. The 'Reading Response' displays, so it seems to actually download the data, but just hangs after doing so. The PWSH window is not responsive to Ctrl+C.

*NOTE*: If testing the below, replace the useragent string with a valid 'Company Name' and 'email address' as per below U.S. sec.gov Webmaster FAQs. When I ran the command I use my own email address with my own custom string (changing the user agent string to something completely different didn't change anything):
https://www.sec.gov/os/webmaster-faq#developers

However, the following equivalent Windows PowerShell 5.1 command works perfectly so seems regression:
$test=invoke-webrequest -uri 'https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/0000008177/000156761917000512/0001567619-17-000512.txt' -useragent 'Private Investor EMAIL@ADDRESS.COM' -usebasicparsing -method get -verbose
PS C:\WINDOWS\system32>

WORKAROUND on Windows only:
$test=& 'powershell.exe' "(invoke-webrequest -uri 'https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/0000008177/000156761917000512/0001567619-17-000512.txt' -useragent 'Private Investor EMAIL@ADDRESS.COM' -usebasicparsing -method get).content"

```console
PS C:\Windows\System32>$test=invoke-webrequest -uri 'https://www.sec.gov/Archives/edgar/data/0000008177/000156761917000512/0001567619-17-000512.txt' -useragent 'Private Investor YOUREMAILADDRESS@EMAILDOMAIN.COM' -SkipHeaderValidation -method GET -verbose
```

- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Remoting cmdlets that support the SSHConnection hash table parameter fail to create session if in the hash table:
`KeyFilePath` is specified using tilde syntax, e.g. `~/.ssh/id_myidentity` instead of full path of the file.
or
`ConnectingTimeout` is not specified.

Steps to reproduce using tilde syntax in the `KeyFilePath`, regardless of `ConnectingTimeout` existence or value:
```
PS /home/user> New-PSSession -SSHConnection @{
    HostName    = 'x.x.x.x'
    Port        = yyyyy
    UserName    = 'administrator'
    KeyFilePath = '~/.ssh/id_myidentity'
}
New-PSSession: [x.x.x.x] An error has occurred which PowerShell cannot handle. A remote session might have ended.
```

Steps to reproduce using full path syntax in the `KeyFilePath` and without specifying `ConnectingTimeout`:
```
PS /home/user> New-PSSession -SSHConnection @{
    HostName    = 'x.x.x.x'
    Port        = yyyyy
    UserName    = 'administrator'
    KeyFilePath = '/home/user/.ssh/id_myidentity'
}
New-PSSession: [x.x.x.x] SSH connection attempt failed after time out: 0 seconds.
```

Command works only when using both full path syntax in the `KeyFilePath` and `ConnectingTimeout` value of `-1` (or something large enough): 
```
PS /home/user> New-PSSession -SSHConnection @{
    HostName          = 'x.x.x.x'
    Port              = yyyyy
    UserName          = 'administrator'
    KeyFilePath       = '/home/user/.ssh/id_myidentity'
    ConnectingTimeout = -1
}
 Id Name            Transport ComputerName    ComputerType    State         ConfigurationName     Availability
 -- ----            --------- ------------    ------------    -----         -----------------     ------------
 39 Runspace38      SSH       x.x.x.x         RemoteMachine   Opened        DefaultShell             Available
```

Splatting the hash table also seem to work regardless of the `KeyFilePath` syntax or `ConnectingTimeout` value:
```
PS /home/user1> $sshparams = @{
    HostName    = 'x.x.x.x'
    Port        = yyyyy
    UserName    = 'administrator'
    KeyFilePath = '~/.ssh/id_myidentity'
}
PS /home/user1> New-PSSession @sshparams

 Id Name            Transport ComputerName    ComputerType    State         ConfigurationName     Availability
 -- ----            --------- ------------    ------------    -----         -----------------     ------------
 47 Runspace46      SSH       x.x.x.x         RemoteMachine   Opened        DefaultShell             Available
```

```console
Connection succeeds with KeyFilePath tilde syntax and without specifying ConnectingTimeout.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
New-PSSession: [x.x.x.x] An error has occurred which PowerShell cannot handle. A remote session might have ended.
```

body:
# PR Summary

Lock and null check of the PrioritySendDataCollection.cs members to avoid race condition.

## PR Context

Copy-Item cmdlet can throw unhandled exception that terminates the process.
The issue occures in WSManTransportManager internals.
The PrioritySendDataCollection class is used by 2 threads: first thread calls ReadOrRegisterCallback method, that gets _dataToBeSent field, when second thread calls Clear method, where _dataToBeSent member is disposed.  

## PR Checklist

- [x] [PR has a meaningful title](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
    - Use the present tense and imperative mood when describing your changes
- [x] [Summarized changes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
- [x] [Make sure all `.h`, `.cpp`, `.cs`, `.ps1` and `.psm1` files have the correct copyright header](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)
- [x] This PR is ready to merge and is not [Work in Progress](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---work-in-progress).
    - If the PR is work in progress, please add the prefix `WIP:` or `[ WIP ]` to the beginning of the title (the `WIP` bot will keep its status check at `Pending` while the prefix is present) and remove the prefix when the PR is ready.
- **[Breaking changes](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#making-breaking-changes)**
    - [x] None
    - **OR**
    - [ ] [Experimental feature(s) needed](https://github.com/MicrosoftDocs/PowerShell-Docs/blob/staging/reference/6/Microsoft.PowerShell.Core/About/about_Experimental_Features.md)
        - [ ] Experimental feature name(s): <!-- Experimental feature name(s) here -->
- **User-facing changes**
    - [x] Not Applicable
    - **OR**
    - [ ] [Documentation needed](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/.github/CONTRIBUTING.md#pull-request---submission)

- **Testing - New and feature**

    - **OR**

- **Tooling**

    - **OR**

### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

$Script:InvariantCulture = [System.Globalization.CultureInfo]::InvariantCulture
$Script:InvariantCultureSessionOption = New-CimSessionOption -Culture $Script:InvariantCulture -UICulture $Script:InvariantCulture -Protocol DCOM
$securePassword = ConvertTo-SecureString "password" -AsPlainText -Force
$credentials = New-Object System.Management.Automation.PSCredential ("Domain\User", $securePassword)
$sessionParameters = @{
ComputerName = "target_name"
SessionOption = $Script:InvariantCultureSessionOption
Credential = $credentials
}
$sessionParameters.Authentication = [Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.Options.PasswordAuthenticationMechanism]::Kerberos
$session = New-CimSession @sessionParameters


(Domain, User, password and target_name replace the original internal information)

### Expected behavior

```console
PS > $session = New-CimSession @sessionParameters
PS > $session


Id           : 4
Name         : CimSession4
InstanceId   : e9c595d5-200d-4d9d-adb7-e1e14c72d20a
ComputerName : target_name
Protocol     : DCOM
```


### Actual behavior

```console
$session = New-CimSession @sessionParameters
The RPC server is unavailable
When looking in wireshark it appears we receive "eRR-S-PRINCIPAL-UNKNOWN (7)" It seems that when the Cim connection is attempting to authenticate the Kerberos it attempts to ask for a ticket to the domain instead of the expected SPN.

We have successfully connected:
1) When not using Kerberos enforcement (the above code without setting the Authentication)
2) Using Kerberos with WinRM (New-PSSession)
3) With legacy WMI methods (that use DCOM)
Get-WmiObject -ComputerName "target_name" -Impersonation Impersonate -Credential $credentials -Class win32_OperatingSystem -Authority "Kerberos:domain\target_name"

With the last example it seems that the SPN it tried to authenticate was the target_name not the domain (as it did in the failed cim connection)
```


### Error details

```console
New-CimSession : The RPC server is unavailable.
At line:1 char:12
+ $session = New-CimSession @sessionParameters
+            ~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~~
    + CategoryInfo          : NotSpecified: (:) [New-CimSession], CimException
    + FullyQualifiedErrorId : HRESULT 0x800706ba,Microsoft.Management.Infrastructure.CimCmdlets.NewCimSessionCommand
    + PSComputerName        : target_name
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      5.1.19041.1023
PSEdition                      Desktop
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0...}
BuildVersion                   10.0.19041.1023
CLRVersion                     4.0.30319.42000
WSManStackVersion              3.0
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
```

_No response_

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

On OSTree-based systems, at least most currently, packages cannot install things into `/usr/local/` as this is part of the "user" space and not the "immutable" space where it can keep track of changes properly: an issue which is outlined at coreos/rpm-ostree#233. This basically affects all `rpm-ostree` based distros, like Fedora Silverblue and Fedora IoT, as well as some other OSTree distros, such as openSUSE MicroOS.

I noticed a similar issue before with the package violating the Debian Policy (#13517), and now I'm curious why PowerShell even _puts_ things in `/usr/local` **as this also violates the FHS**: `/usr/local` is for the user, while `/usr` is for packages managed by the system.

The actual part of the package the installer complains about is the man pages it looks like, as outlined below.
```
$ sudo rpm-ostree install powershell
[...]
error: importing RPMs: Importing package 'powershell': Analyzing /usr/local/share/man/man1/pwsh.1.gz: Unsupported path; see https://github.com/projectatomic/rpm-ostree/issues/233
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_
