body:
### Background and Description

I'm trying to run `Write-Error boomed` with `pwsh -EncodedCommand VwByAGkAdABlAC0ARQByAHIAbwByACAAYgBvAG8AbQBlAGQA`, and I'm expecting the following output: 

```
Write-Error: boomed
```

And it works pretty well. However, running this command without pseudo-tty, will cause it to print some meaningless characters. I'm using `ssh -T localhost xxx` to run without tty, and `ssh -tt localhost xxx` to run with tty. And I'm getting the following test results: 

||with tty (-tt)|without tty (-T)|
|---|---|---|
|Windows powershell 5.1|good|messed up|
|Linux powershell 7|good|messed up|

### Steps to reproduce

Run 

```bash
ssh -T localhost pwsh -EncodedCommand VwByAGkAdABlAC0ARQByAHIAbwByACAAYgBvAG8AbQBlAGQA
```

### Expected output in stderr

```console
Write-Error: boomed
```


### Actual output in stderr

```console
#< CLIXML
<Objs Version="1.1.0.1" xmlns="http://schemas.microsoft.com/powershell/2004/04"><S S="Error">_x001B_[91mWrite-Error: _x001B_[91mboomed_x001B_[0m_x000A_</S></Objs>
```


### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.1.3
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.1.3
OS                             Linux 5.15.10-hardened1-1-hardened #1 SMP PREEMPT Fri, 17 Dec 2021 20:16:31 +0000
Platform                       Unix
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0

# Note that this problem also exists in powershell 5.1 on Windows.
```


### Visuals

![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/19610256/147651227-5b5c9820-7c36-4742-ad9c-20b98c249f53.png)

### What have I tried

I have tried setting `$WarningPreference = "SilentlyContinue"`. After setting this variable, I can run  `[Console]::Error.WriteLine('xxx')` with `pwsh -EncodedCommand` without any issue. But `Write-Error xxx` is still messing up the terminal. 

### Ref

<https://github.com/ansible/ansible/issues/67964>

<https://stackoverflow.com/questions/51634308/start-process-using-encodedcommand-outputs-to-standard-error>

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

This issue is related to #16298 [`String` >>>Regex>>> `PSCustomObject`](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/issues/16257) which is closed after it moved to a discussion (not sure about the exact reason it is closed, meaning that I might make the same mistake here).

Anyways, reading from a fix text table usually generated from an external program is something that is quiet often required noting the concerned StackOverflow questions, like:
* [Convert Formatted String Output with empty cells to PS Object](https://stackoverflow.com/a/69118599/1701026)
* [Powershell String to csv (netstat -ano)](https://stackoverflow.com/q/65346664/1701026)
* [convert list output to table(object)](https://stackoverflow.com/a/60882963/1701026)
* [Convert System.String to object](https://stackoverflow.com/q/56964468/1701026)
* [Another grep / awk q, parsing diskpart output](https://stackoverflow.com/q/42680382/1701026)
* [How to read powershell table from file](https://stackoverflow.com/a/53364959/1701026)
* [Split string on arbitrary-length substrings (Powershell)](https://stackoverflow.com/a/55752375/1701026)
* [ConvertFrom-Sting Template Parsing Failure with Array](https://stackoverflow.com/q/52835623/1701026)
* [How can I use powershell to intercept a specified string of a command output?](https://stackoverflow.com/a/51279071/1701026)

As you can see from some of the answers, I have created my own "solution" for this: [`ConvertFrom-SourceTable`](https://www.powershellgallery.com/packages?q=convertfrom-sourcetable) but I would expect a more standard way using the `ConvertFrom-String` with e.g. a `-Table` parameter.

Besides from converting the output of an external program, it could be useful to build a human readable" in-script source/settings table.

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

```PowerShell
$Colors = ConvertFrom-SourceTable ' # ConvertFrom-String -Table
	Name       Value         RGB
	----       -----         ---
	Black   0x000000       0,0,0
	White   0xFFFFFF 255,255,255
	Red     0xFF0000     255,0,0
	Lime    0x00FF00     0,255,0
	Blue    0x0000FF     0,0,255
	Yellow  0xFFFF00   255,255,0
	Cyan    0x00FFFF   0,255,255
	Magenta 0xFF00FF   255,0,255
	Silver  0xC0C0C0 192,192,192
	Gray    0x808080 128,128,128
	Maroon  0x800000     128,0,0
	Olive   0x808000   128,128,0
	Green   0x008000     0,128,0
	Purple  0x800080   128,0,128
	Teal    0x008080   0,128,128
	Navy    0x000080     0,0,128'
```

labels.description: the issue is more of a feature request than a bug
labels.name: Issue-Enhancement

title: Add table support to `ConvertFrom-String`

title: Update metadata for picking up .NET 6 RC2 version

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Type in the following:
```
function Get-VM {throw "Why was I run?"}
Enter-PSSession -VMName VM1 -Credential (Get-Credential)
```
And note how the error message is the same that we just added to Get-VM.
If we look at the code: https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/6c22065d77f0d150484ac0234938b0afb7ee11f1/src/System.Management.Automation/engine/remoting/commands/newrunspacecommand.cs#L879 we can see that it runs the script `Get-VM -Name $args` and because of the command precedence rules, the function is run instead of the cmdlet.  
A simple solution to this would be to just run the command with the module qualified name: `Hyper-V\Get-VM` and that's how it's done elsewhere in this project but that doesn't solve the issue of someone intentionally overriding the module like this: `New-Module -ScriptBlock {function Get-VM{throw "Why was I run?"}} -Name Hyper-V` is there a better way to do it?

### Expected behavior

```console
A session to VM1.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Exception: Why was I run?
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PS C:\> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.0-preview.10
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.0-preview.10
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19044

PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

title: PowerShell will sometimes use the wrong command in internal command calls

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

Running $test.ps1 as part of a scheduled task via an administrative user intermittently shows the below error.
I've never been able to reproduce the problem by executing the $test.ps1 script in Visual Studio Code, opening PWSH from Start > Run As Administrator, etc.
It seems correlated to when the computer is under heavy usage of memory and CPU, which may be part of the perceived non-deterministism.
Computer has latest drivers, BIOS, firmware, and updates applied, with AV turned off.

$test.ps1
```
. c:\scripts\check.ps1
```

check.ps1
```
try{
    $null=import-module -name PackageManagement,powershellget
    if((get-installedmodule -name simplysql -ea 0).count -eq 0){
        $null=(install-module -acceptlicense -name SimplySql -scope currentuser)
    }
}catch{
    $ei_h=$_
    $ge_h=get-error
    $exception_h=$ei_h.Exception
    $line_h=$ei_h.InvocationInfo.ScriptLineNumber
    $msg_h=$ei_h.Message 
    $stringerr_h=-join('Error. Investigate.',"`n",'$line_h=',$line_h,"`n",'$exception_h=',"`n",$exception_h,"`n",'$msg_h=',"`n",$msg_h,"`n",'get-error=',"`n",$ge_h)
    $mtoday_h=get-date -uformat '%Y%m%d%H%M'
    $problem_h="$env:userprofile\$mtoday_h-problem.txt"
    $streamp_h=[System.IO.StreamWriter]$problem_h
    $streamp_h.write($stringerr_h)
    $streamp_h.close()
    exit 1
}
```

test.xml
```

        <DaysInterval>1</DaysInterval>
      </ScheduleByDay>
    </CalendarTrigger>
  </Triggers>
  <Principals>

      <UserId>S-1-5-21-4026033148-167229773-3407019803-1001</UserId>
      <LogonType>Password</LogonType>
      <RunLevel>HighestAvailable</RunLevel>
    </Principal>
  </Principals>
  <Settings>
    <MultipleInstancesPolicy>IgnoreNew</MultipleInstancesPolicy>
    <DisallowStartIfOnBatteries>false</DisallowStartIfOnBatteries>
    <StopIfGoingOnBatteries>true</StopIfGoingOnBatteries>
    <AllowHardTerminate>false</AllowHardTerminate>
    <StartWhenAvailable>true</StartWhenAvailable>
    <RunOnlyIfNetworkAvailable>false</RunOnlyIfNetworkAvailable>
    <IdleSettings>
      <StopOnIdleEnd>true</StopOnIdleEnd>
      <RestartOnIdle>false</RestartOnIdle>
    </IdleSettings>
    <AllowStartOnDemand>true</AllowStartOnDemand>
    <Enabled>true</Enabled>
    <Hidden>false</Hidden>
    <RunOnlyIfIdle>false</RunOnlyIfIdle>
    <DisallowStartOnRemoteAppSession>false</DisallowStartOnRemoteAppSession>
    <UseUnifiedSchedulingEngine>true</UseUnifiedSchedulingEngine>
    <WakeToRun>false</WakeToRun>
    <ExecutionTimeLimit>PT0S</ExecutionTimeLimit>
    <Priority>7</Priority>
  </Settings>
  <Actions Context="Author">
    <Exec>
      <Command>pwsh.exe</Command>
      <Arguments>-nologo -windowstyle hidden -ExecutionPolicy Bypass -command ". c:\scripts\test.ps1; exit $LASTEXITCODE"</Arguments>
      <WorkingDirectory>c:\scripts</WorkingDirectory>
    </Exec>
  </Actions>
</Task>
```

### Expected behavior

title: PWSH 7.2.1: System.Management.Automation.ParameterBindingException: A parameter cannot be found that matches parameter name 'Provider'.

body:
### Summary of the new feature / enhancement

Specifying comma at the end is common error. I personally use PowerShell from version 2 and still have this issue frequently. 

I propose new line to be delimiter equivalent to `,`. This currently errors so I think it doesn't break compatibility

```powershell
function foo {
   parms(
      [string] $x
      [string] $y
      [string] $z
   )
}
```

As equivalent to 


```powershell
function foo {
   parms(
      [string] $x,
      [string] $y,
      [string] $z
   )
}
```

Another idea to minimize this error would be to tolerate trailing `,` on last parameter:

```powershell
function foo {
   parms(
      [string] $x,
      [string] $y,
      [string] $z,
   )
}
```

### Proposed technical implementation details (optional)

_No response_

When I try to upgrade to pwsh 7.2.1 on my Windows laptops, I get a dialog that says "installation terminated prematurely." This happens if I let vscode try to do the upgrade if I try to do the upgrade via winget, and if I download the MSI and attempt the upgrade manually.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

`.ForEach()` has an overload that allows setting property values by name and (array of) property values.

This works in general, but unexpectedly not with  a _single_ `[pscustomobject]` instance (as later discovered, it _does_ work with _arrays_ of `[pscustomobject]` instances).

```powershell
($obj = [pscustomobject] @{ p = 1 }).ForEach('p', 42)
```

### Expected behavior

No output, and `$obj.p` should report `42` afterwards.

### Actual behavior

`1` - the current property value - is output, and the attempt to assign a new value is ignored.

### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PowerShell Core 7.3.0-preview.1
```


### Visuals

_No response_

labels.description: Issue has been identified as a bug in the product
labels.name: Issue-Bug

labels.description: core PowerShell engine, interpreter, and runtime
labels.name: WG-Engine

labels.description: The issue is fixed.
labels.name: Resolution-Fixed

title: Setting property values with the .ForEach() array method doesn't work with a single [pscustomobject] instance.

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

When $ErrorView is set to NormalView (or CategoryView), error text color changes from red to white. When checking the current value of $Host.PrivateData.ErrorForegroundColor it reports Red. It is possible to change the variable value but it has no effect in NormalView and CategoryView.
In ConciseView everything works as expected.

### Expected behavior

```console
Error text color should be the same as the $Host.PrivateData.ErrorForegroundColor value.
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Error text color is white whatever color you set to $Host.PrivateData.ErrorForegroundColor.
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```

body:
### Prerequisites

- [X] Write a descriptive title.
- [X] Make sure you are able to repro it on the [latest released version](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/releases)
- [X] Search the existing issues.
- [X] Refer to the [FAQ](https://github.com/PowerShell/PowerShell/blob/master/docs/FAQ.md).
- [X] Refer to [Differences between Windows PowerShell 5.1 and PowerShell](https://docs.microsoft.com/powershell/scripting/whats-new/differences-from-windows-powershell).

### Steps to reproduce

- Create a new junction (reparse point) of an arbitrary directory
```powershell
New-Item -Path junction -ItemType Junction -Value 'C:\Program Files\'
```
- Create a new symbolic link of an arbitrary directory
```powershell
New-Item -Path symlink -ItemType SymbolicLink -Value 'C:\Program Files\'
```
- Run the `Remove-Item` command with the `-WhatIf` switch parameter
```powershell
Remove-Item -Path .\junction\ -WhatIf
Remove-Item -Path .\symlink\ -WhatIf
```

### Expected behavior

```console
Should not remove junction or symbolic link
```


### Actual behavior

```console
Removes the junction and symbolic link
```


### Error details

_No response_

### Environment data

```powershell
PS C:\Users\tospaa> $PSVersionTable

Name                           Value
----                           -----
PSVersion                      7.2.1
PSEdition                      Core
GitCommitId                    7.2.1
OS                             Microsoft Windows 10.0.19043
Platform                       Win32NT
PSCompatibleVersions           {1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0…}
PSRemotingProtocolVersion      2.3
SerializationVersion           1.1.0.1
WSManStackVersion              3.0
```
